title: Ted Baker can't keep blaming the weather or 'market conditions' says EMILY HARDY
text:
Ted Baker is going through the wringer.

Its shares are worth a quarter of their price just six months ago - with falls of 35 per cent yesterday and another 10 per cent today - in the wake of three profit warnings, falling sales and a harassment scandal.

Allegations of ‘enforced hugging’ were levelled at its founder and boss Ray Kelvin, who stepped down in March and handed the mantel to Lindsay Page.

Ted Baker, founded in 1988, has issued three profit warnings in the past seven months

But, despite some efforts to get things back on track, new management has not yet found a way to stem the decay.

This week's dire half-year results, as it swung to a half-year loss, only cemented investor’s fears that Ted Baker’s issues aren’t about to go away any time soon.

In fact, it looked as though things could be about to get even worse as the firm warned that profits in the second half of the year would be lower unless market conditions improved.

Ted Baker said that poor weather in September hurt sales

But, nearly a year in, I’m not buying the whole external 'market conditions' narrative anymore.

Clearly, well documented challenges – weak consumer confidence, rival discounting, the weak pound – are significant factors to which Ted Baker is not immune.

It may have also been knocked (to some extent) by reputational damage around Kelvin’s alleged behaviour. No doubt the company was rocked to the core when the crisis emerged in March.

But this is Ted Baker, which just a year ago was still regarded a high street hero – admirably keeping pace with the rapid shifts in the retail industry and defying all that doom and gloom.

Shareholders continued to pour in, safe in the knowledge that whatever happened in the sector resilient, popular Ted Baker would inevitably come out one of retail’s winners.

A short term wobble – such as that experienced even by Primark in November – could have been deemed acceptable given the tough trading environment. A bad quarter here or there, perhaps.

But three profit warnings in seven months?

Those are the sort of headlines reserved for older, far weaker operators – Bonmarche, New Look, House of Fraser, Mothercare – the firms that had already fallen behind and required radical structural change in order to weather the High Street storm.

So, with each passing month, it's starting to look more and more like Ted Baker’s problems could stem from within.

Let's take its half-year results: Other than in the US, Ted Baker reported sales declines across all its markets. Even more worryingly, online sales fell.

Can all that be pinned on 'external conditions' and ‘unseasonable weather’?

The crash in its shares yesterday – a 35 per cent fall – betrayed investors’ suspicions too that this may no longer be just a bump in the road that Ted Baker can easily ride out.

Apart from the US, Ted Baker reported sales declines in all its markets over the past six months

Alarm bells started ringing for me when, at a race day two years ago, a friend and I played ‘Spot The Ted Baker Dress’ – the brand's distinctive floral designs standing out a mile.

We spotted at least 15 women wearing the exact same navy blue Ted Baker gown that day – and while they all looked fantastic, they stole each other’s thunder, just as they would have done if they’d arrived at a wedding in the same dress.

I've seen it happen to men too. The problem with Ted's standout shirts with snazzy collars and cuff embellishments is that they... stand out, prompting that agonising Ted Baker ‘snap’ moment at many an office party.

There was THAT Ted Baker coat as well (you know the one), which around 40 per cent of the women in my office wore two winters back.

It’s not exactly what you hope for when you splash out on something ‘a little bit different’.

It was back then I first suspected we were about to reach peak Ted Baker, and I believe its appeal has waned since - like with any restaurant chain that rapidly over-expands and subsequently loses its charm.

I’ve also become unsure about the audience Ted Baker is trying to target.

Its gone down the strange Superdry route of ranges for children – a sure fire way to disengage teenage and young shoppers.

It’s also marketing at middle aged men – as if might be desirable for young guys to step out in the same brand as their dads.

Ted Baker, like Superdry, has a range of children's clothes - as demonstrated above

The brand is also targeting slightly older shoppers as it branches out into fresh markets

To be fair, perhaps it is, but I do think it’s quite an accomplishment for any brand to bridge that gap and appeal to ‘every man’.

Analysts were nervous when teenage favourite Boohoo bought Karen Millen earlier this year because they feared the firm might neglect its loyal core shopper base.

Clearly, it's far from doomsday for Ted Baker, and it's still early days for new boss Page too. Decisive action to distance the firm from chaotic department stores, for example, will certainty do it some favours.

But if Ted Baker wants to win loyal shoppers, it needs to stop looking out of the window at the weather, and take a long, hard look in the mirror instead.
